author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Trump Reverses Course on Russia Sanctions - Risk & Compliance Journal. - WSJ
text:
0 COMMENTS U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at the White House on April 13, 2018. Photo: MANDEL NGAN/AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE/GETTY IMAGES
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
The World Bank penalized a Kenyan railway project over corruption. (SG)
Bribe-takers in Liberia aren’t off the hook . (DO)
An Israeli court convicted a judge for ethics violations in the country’s bribery probe of the premier. Separately, police want to indict the former coalition chair on bribery charges ; his lawyers said he’s innocent. (Haaretz, i24, JP, ToI)
Will Brexit lead to bribery ? (Observer)
Local cases: A former New York prosecutor’s bribery trial started . The corruption trial of a former Long Island county commissioner continues . (NYP, NYDN, Newsday)
Cybercrime:
The U.S. and U.K. blamed Russia for global cyberattacks . (Reuters, BBC, Guardian, AFP)
Hackers once stole a casino’s high-roller database through a thermometer in a lobby fish tank. (BI)
Fraud:
Washington, D.C., school officials tasked with preventing enrollment fraud are often committing it. (WP)
Money Laundering:
Latvia is scrambling to clean the stain of money laundering from its financial sector. A top Latvian official is in the U.S. to brief Washington. (AFP, LSM)
The shutdown of Backpage.com and concurrent money-laundering charges, may have pushed sex workers into the shadows. (Quartz)
Antigua’s premier slammed the U.S. over a report on the island’s anti-money laundering enforcement. (AN)
Romania changed its transaction reporting requirements to clean up money laundering. (BR)
Islamic banks are facing an uneven impact due to de-risking. (Reuters)
Angola’s government said the former president’s son tried to steal $1.5 billion; the story didn’t contain a response. (AJE, M&G)
Sanctions:
U.S. President Donald Trump put the brakes on new sanctions against Russia, undercutting his U.N. ambassador, who announced on TV a plan to impose them. (WP, ES, MJ, TS, Slate)
Is a Laotian casino operator targeted by the U.S. for sanctions for wildlife trafficking also behind drug trafficking and child prostitution? The operator didn’t respond to requests for comment. (SCMP)
European diplomats failed to agree on new Iran sanctions. (Reuters, AP)
Russian oligarchs have more to fear than sanctions . (DB, WSJ)
Transparency:
Four thousand toddlers are listed as U.K. business owners, showing how easy it is to exploit the British corporate registry. A U.K. whistleblower is being prosecuted for warning about frauds through Companies House. (Quartz, Mirror)
Critics say expense reform for members of the European parliament is inadequate . (Politico)
Whistleblowers:
The EU is set to move forward with whistleblower legislation. (Guardian)
General Anti-Corruption:
South African police raided the compound of an influential family with ties to the ousted former president, taking $21 million in assets. The former president and the family deny wrongdoing. How did the party of Nelson Mandela turn so corrupt? (Reuters, Bloomberg, NYT, NYT)
The attorneys working the Michael Cohen case come from the public-corruption unit . (Quartz, NY, NYT)
Brazil’s former president still leads in the polls despite his detainment in prison following a corruption conviction. Protesters briefly took over the apartment at the center of the allegations against him. Could he be freed ? (AP, AP, Guardian, Reuters)
The top U.S. environmental protection official broke the law with the purchase of a soundproof phone booth, government watchdogs said. The agency is addressing the issue, a spokeswoman said. (HuffPost, ABC, WP, BuzzFeed)
China launched a website for people to report when they spot fugitives and corrupt officials. (AFP)
Samsung denied a media report it launched illicit lobbying to help bring the 2018 Winter Olympics to South Korea. (AP)
Hundreds rallied in Malaysia against kleptocracy. Thousands of Slovaks protested corruption . (ST, Euronews, Reuters)
The former finance chief of a company was sent to prison for embezzling millions . (AP, KCS)
An Egyptian court cleared the final corruption allegations against a businessman. (EI)
The U.S. Supreme Court once again rejected the appeal of former Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich to overturn his corruption conviction. (CT)
